name: GJ 876
scenarioDescription:
The GJ 876 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 876 is a star with 0.32 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.3 times its radius. It is located 15.264100799999998 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 1 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 876 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 876 system

GJ 876 b

GJ 876 b was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the Radial Velocity method. The mass of GJ 876 b is 723.2235 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 876 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 876 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


GJ 876 c

GJ 876 c was discovered by the Multiple Observatories observatory using the Radial Velocity method. The mass of GJ 876 c is 226.9846 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 876 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 876 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


GJ 876 d

GJ 876 d was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory using the Radial Velocity method. The mass of GJ 876 d is 6.83 times the mass of Earth. At 6.83 Earth masses, GJ 876 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


GJ 876 e

GJ 876 e was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory using the Radial Velocity method. The mass of GJ 876 e is 14.6 times the mass of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, GJ 876 e is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system GJ 876, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Multiple Observatories.
